appeals.sector: Middle East and North Africa Regional Office

field_reports.summary: LBN: Population Movement - 03-2025 - LBN: Population Movement from Syria to Akkar, Lebanon - 03-2025 (2025-03-14) #2 (2025-03-14)
field_reports.description:
Lebanon has witnessed a new wave of displacement from Syria due to intensified hostilities in the coastal regions, particularly affecting Tartous, Lattakia, Homs, and Hama Governorates. 

Recent displacement has led to the arrival of 10,500 new individuals in Akkar and the North Governorate, with the majority (8,828 people) settling in Akkar. These arrivals are in addition to an already vulnerable population of 90,500 displaced persons in Baalback/Hermel. The movement into Lebanon has been exacerbated by insecure roads, forcing many to cross at night on foot through rivers and unsafe areas. Many of the new arrivals, including female-headed households who lost their spouses in Syria, are currently sheltered in substandard conditions—either with relatives, in overcrowded homes, or in two large unofficial collective shelters housing approximately 1,500 individuals.

The Lebanese government has not yet approved the opening of official collective shelters, which limits the humanitarian response options. Municipalities, already under financial strain, have expressed difficulties in sustaining assistance without external support.

field_reports.summary: LBN: Complex Emergency - 09-2024 - LRC Conflict Response #1 (2024-09-24)
field_reports.description:
Following the darkest week of conflict in Lebanon after the explosion of pagers and wireless devices, yesterday, September 23, 2024, marked the deadliest day in Lebanon in years, with 300 simultaneous airstrikes targeted multiple locations in a single day, resulting nearly 600 people were killed, and at least 4,766 were injured, with the toll expected to rise significantly as rescue efforts continue. Alongside the growing number of civilian casualties, thousands of families have been forced to flee their homes.

Between October 2023 and September 2024, over 100,000 people  were displaced, with that number expected to have significantly increased following the Israeli-issued mass displacement orders to residents in southern Lebanon and Bekaa regions.

The situation in Lebanon is very tense. All the roads leading to Beirut from the South and the Beqaa Valley are now flooded with thousands of people attempting to flee the bombardment, leaving everything behind. Schools and other places that can serve as shelters for displaced populations are being identified and operated.

Almost half the population (44%) was already below the poverty line in 2024, with many suffering from food insecurity. Hospitals, which were operating on minimum resources before this crisis, are now unable to cope with the overwhelming demands of large-scale emergency.

results.summary:
Lebanon’s southern border has been the scene of continued conflict since 8 October 2023, evoking memories of the 2006 conflict and its profound impact on the region. Following the explosion of thousands of pagers on 17 September 2024, the hostilities have escalated dramatically. Southern Lebanon, the Bekaa region and Beirut’s suburbs have seen a massive increase in airstrikes and attacks, leading to over 2,710 deaths and 12,592 injuries as of 28 October 2024. This recent escalation has led to widespread destruction and mass displacement, exacerbating an already dire socio-economic situation in the country.

Lebanese authorities estimate that over 1.1 million individuals have been displaced, including many Syrian and Palestinian refugees, with some households being displaced multiple times. Many people left their homes quickly, without their essential items. Livelihoods are also severely disrupted, particularly for farming communities.

Around half of all displaced people are currently living in host settings, often in overcrowded conditions. The Lebanese Government has also opened 1,118 new collective shelters in public schools and other buildings that currently host over 188,690 displaced individuals (43,586 families), based on the household registration efforts of the Lebanese Red Cross and the Lebanese Government. However, limited access to safe and adequate shelter for internally displaced people (IDPs), as well as registration for displaced refugees and migrants, remains a challenge, particularly as winter approaches, increasing the humanitarian needs for those in makeshift housing and overcrowded centres. 

The large-scale displacement has heightened demand for essentials like bread, water, and shelter, placing the market system under pressure, and with 

prices already significantly inflated in some areas. Moreover, the hostilities have not only inflicted heavy civilian casualties, but have also severely damaged civilian infrastructure, including water and sanitation facilities, cutting off access to clean water for tens of thousands. The lack of effective sanitation services, with most wastewater treatment plants non-operational due to power shortages, heightens the risk of disease outbreaks like cholera, which had already severely affected Lebanon in late 2022.

Lebanon's healthcare sector, already strained by the economic crisis and COVID-19, faces critical shortages of medical staff and supplies, making it increasingly challenging to meet the needs of displaced people and those with chronic health conditions. Lebanese hospitals and health facilities are overwhelmed by the surge in casualties. Out of 207 primary health care centres and dispensaries in conflict-affected areas, 100 are already closed. Mobile Medical Units (MMU) from the Lebanese Red Cross have been deployed to mitigate this, but the overall healthcare system in Lebanon remains severely overwhelmed.
results.name: Lebanon Complex Emergency - 2024

appeals.sector: Middle East and North Africa Regional Office

field_reports.description:
Since October 7, 2023, the humanitarian situation in the Gaza Strip has been dire following the recent escalation of violence. According to the United Nations, Over 1 million people have been displaced from their homes in the Gaza Strip, and thousands of homes and businesses have been destroyed. The conflict has also caused widespread damage to infrastructure, including hospitals, schools, and water and electricity systems. 


In addition to the destruction of property, the conflict has also had a devastating impact on people's lives. The total statistics according to the Palestinian Ministry of Health show that Gaza reported cases since the beginning of the events 4,137 deaths, in addition to more than 13,162 injuries. Most of the injuries are caused by shrapnel and gunshot wounds. The conflict has also caused widespread trauma and psychological distress. 

The total cases dealt with by PRCS ambulance teams since the beginning of the events are (6007) cases, including 1464 fatalities and 4543 injuries.

The health system in the Gaza Strip is struggling to cope with the influx of casualties. Hospitals are overcrowded, and medical supplies are running low. The power grid is also damaged, making it difficult to operate hospitals and other essential services. Since the start of the escalation of hostilities, four schools and eight healthcare facilities in Gaza have sustained damage.

Since the closure of the border, 105 Palestinians have been stuck on the Egyptian side of the border. They are suffering from a lack of food, medication, and shelter.

The already dire humanitarian context inside Gaza is deteriorating further, resulting in large-scale displacement inside Gaza and potentially across the Rafah border into Egypt.
Drawing from past escalation events and historical context, Egypt has played a crucial role in facilitating medical treatment for critically injured individuals evacuated to its hospitals, hosting displaced populations, and acting as a channel for humanitarian aid destined for the Gaza Strip, either originating from Egypt or dispatched internationally through it. The Egyptian Red Crescent is the only organization with access to North Sinai and already holds operations and projects in the area.

Today on the 21st of October 2023, a total of 20 ERCS trucks crossed the Rafah borders carrying aid that is based on the coordinated needs of PRCS, which included

  • Six trucks carrying: Medicine
  • Seven trucks: Medical Consumbles
  • Five trucks: Food Items.
  • Two trucks: Water

The trucks make their way into Gaza through the PRCS, in coordination with authorities on both sides to ensure the safe delivery of items.

Since 7 October 2023, The humanitarian situation in the Gaza Strip is dire following the recent escalation of violence. According to the United Nations Over 187,518 people have been displaced from their homes in the Gaza Strip, and thousands of homes and businesses have been destroyed. The conflict has also caused widespread damage to infrastructure, including hospitals, schools, and water and electricity systems. About 3,000 Palestinians in Gaza are still displaced following previous escalations.(1)

In addition to the destruction of property, the conflict has also had a devastating impact on people's lives. The total statistics according to the Palestinian Ministry of Health that Gaza reported cases since the beginning of the events (1100) Deaths, including (270) children and (240) women, in addition to more than (5339) injuries. The majority of the injuries are caused by shrapnel and gunshot wounds. The conflict has also caused widespread trauma and psychological distress. (2)

The total cases dealt with by PRCS ambulance teams since the beginning of the events are (2492) cases, including
(478) fatalities and (2014) injuries.

The displacement of a very large number of citizens from the border areas in the governorates to the heart of the cities
was recorded in shelter centers or with host families, as the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Refugees
(UNRWA) announced that its centers received more than 200,000 displaced people in its shelter centers, while official sources announced The number of displaced people has increased to more than 330,000 in different regions.

The health system in the Gaza Strip is struggling to cope with the influx of casualties. Hospitals are overcrowded and medical supplies are running low. The power grid is also damaged, making it difficult to operate hospitals and other essential services. Since the start of the escalation of hostilities, four schools and eight healthcare facilities in Gaza have sustained damage.

Since the closure of the border, 37 Palestinians have been stuck on the Egyptian side of the border. They are suffering from a lack of food, medication, and shelter.
The already dire humanitarian context inside Gaza is deteriorating further resulting in large-scale displacement inside Gaza and potentially across the Rafah border into Egypt.

It is Israel will keep all entry and exit points to Gaza, closed for the coming months and as will not allow the opening of a humanitarian corridor for emergency goods and into Gaza. 

Drawing from past escalation events and historical context, Egypt has played a crucial role in facilitating medical treatment for critically injured individuals evacuated to its hospitals, hosting displaced populations, and acting as a channel for humanitarian aid destined for the Gaza Strip, either originating from Egypt or dispatched internationally through it. The Egyptian Red Crescent is the only organization with access to North Sinai and already holds operations and projects in the area.

In the wake of a notable escalation in conflict within Palestine and the increasing tensions at the Lebanese Southern borders, a disturbing scenario reminiscent of the 2006 war between Lebanon and Israel begins to unfold. This scenario depicts an armed conflict primarily involving Hezbollah and Israel. The conflict manifests as a series of intense air raids and attacks, strategically targeting not only the southern regions of Lebanon but also the densely populated southern suburbs of Beirut, the agriculturally rich north of Bekaa, and the border areas, leaving a trail of destruction in its wake. In addition to the external dangers, internal political/security instability poses an imminent risk to inter/intra-communal groups. Scenario Assumptions: • Hezbollah-Israel Armed Conflict • Air Raids and Rocket Attacks • Internal Displacement • Lebanese Armed Forces (LAF) involvement • Blockades and Naval Operations • Risks to Syrian Refugees • Foreign Involvement

results.summary:
Since 7 October 2023, hostilities have significantly escalated across the Gaza Strip and the West Bank, leading to a severe humanitarian crisis in the occupied Palestinian territories (oPt). The situation continues to deteriorate rapidly, with increasing casualties, damaged infrastructure, restricted access, and mass internal displacement.

As of 15 September 2024, more than 41,252 Palestinians have been killed in Gaza [OCHA]. Over 1.9 million people in Gaza are estimated to be internally displaced [OCHA]. The Gaza Strip has been under an electricity blackout since 11 October 2023, and a severe fuel shortage has led to the closure of most hospitals, particularly in the north. This has increased the pressure on remaining medical facilities and resulted in a rise in medical evacuations to neighboring countries.

Food and water supplies in Gaza are critically low, with only a fraction of the needed aid arriving through the borders. Humanitarian access remains highly restricted, with significant challenges including fuel shortages, communication shutdowns, and stringent restrictions. Safe passage for humanitarian aid remains key to deliver life-saving supplies. [OCHA]

In the West Bank, as of 10 September 2024, at least 705 Palestinians have been killed and over 5,700 injured since 7 October 2023 [OCHA]. The region has seen a significant increase in violence: between 7 October 2023 and 12 August 2024, OCHA recorded around 1,250 attacks by Israeli settlers against Palestinians, leading to fatalities, injuries, and property damage. 

The humanitarian situation is further compounded by movement restrictions. This has disrupted access to essential services, including healthcare, which has faced over 500 attacks since October 2023. Displacement is also a major issue with 88 thousands IDPs according to UN reports.

Meanwhile, increased conflicts along the southern borders of Lebanon in recent months, with a spike in September 2024, have led to a sharp increase in internal displacement, with different reports indicating the number of IDPs as anywhere between 200,000 upwards to the hundreds of thousands. As of 27 September 2024, at least 1640 civilians have been killed, and 8408 injured. [MoPH]. Lebanon is experiencing a multi-layered crisis, exacerbated by the ongoing conflict. The country is dealing with a protracted political, financial, and socio-economic crisis, which has severely impacted the availability and affordability of basic services such as healthcare, education, and clean water.

The International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies (IFRC) and its National Societies have been providing critical assistance, including medical care, food, water, and shelter. Despite these efforts, the scale of the crisis requires more resources and support to meet the growing needs.
results.name: Middle East Crisis | MENA

field_reports.summary: LBN: Civil Unrest - 2023-07 - Ain Al Helwe Clashes
field_reports.description:
Deadly clashes between rival groups in South Lebanon, Saida’s Ain al-Hilweh Palestinian refugee camp have been ongoing since Saturday 29th  July 2023, killing more than 12 individuals and injuring more than 60 as more than half of the camps residents fled their homes, security sources inside the camp stated. 

Among the injured was a Lebanese Army soldier who was hurt by shrapnel from a mortar shell that fell on a military barracks, the army announced on Twitter. The soldier’s condition was described as stable.

In-fighting is still at large at the time of writing, with automatic machine guns, Rocket Propelled Grenades, and medium sized artilary being used by the multiple factions. The fighting was started on Saturday after the assasination of a Palestinian Command official.

results.summary:
Deadly clashes between rival groups in South Lebanon, Saida’s Ain al-Hilweh Palestinian refugee camp have been ongoing since Saturday 29th  July 2023, killing more than 14 individuals and injuring more than 60 as more than half of the camps residents fled their homes, security sources inside the camp stated. 

Among the injured was a Lebanese Army soldier who was hurt by shrapnel from a mortar shell that fell on a military barracks, the army announced on Twitter. The soldier’s condition was described as stable.

In-fighting is still at large at the time of writing, with automatic machine guns, Rocket Propelled Grenades, and medium sized artilary being used by the multiple factions. The fighting was started on Saturday after the assasination of a Palestinian Command official.
results.name: LBN: Civil Unrest - 2023-07 - Ain Al Helwe Clashes

appeals.sector: Middle East and North Africa Regional Office

field_reports.description:
Lebanon has been facing severe weather conditions since the 19th of January 2023. Adverse conditions intensified by the end of January, thus deepening the already existing vulnerabilities in the country, particularly for populations that are already at risk. Heavy rain, precipitation, cold temperatures, and strong winds have led to the inundation of roads and heightened traffic safety risks across the country. These factors have also aggravated health risks for those living in inadequate shelter, including displaced Syrians in informal tented settlements (ITS), Palestinians living in undermaintained camps, and Lebanese already struggling with the socio-economic collapse.

 

As of the 3rd of February, UNHCR, through Inter-Agency Coordination, reported an estimated 1388 individuals affected by the weather conditions in Syrian ITSs. Moreover, by the 6th of February, the Lebanese Government had not yet estimated the overall number of people affected; however, the local and state media reported an increase in traffic incidents, road closures at high altitudes, and at least 3 cases of drowning related to the winter rains.

 

This comes as Lebanon is attempting to recover from a Cholera outbreak in late 2022 and has an overstretched healthcare system.

 

In the early morning hours of the 6th of February, a 7.8 magnitude earthquake struck Southern Turkey and Northern Syria. The earthquake’s epicenter is located 450 km from Beirut and the earthquake was felt in all Lebanese regions at a 4.8 magnitude. Damages are still being assessed and the risks of aftershocks and potential damages could unfold as the severe weather continues.

 

LRC through its presence throughout Lebanon and across its operational sectors supported all communities (host and non-host).

 

1. LRCs 140 Emergency Hotline received many calls directly after the Earthquake while Emergency Medical Teams has been on alert since 3:20 A.M and transported and treated 18 cases.

2. LRCs Disaster Management Sector has provided support to 600 HHs in Akkar with the provision of blankets, bread and other relief items.

3. LRCs Disaster Risk Reduction Unit launched the dissemination of the earthquake awareness video and the booklet including the main key messages.

4. LRCs 1760 Non-emergency Hotline received more than 20 calls requesting information about evacuations and safety measures, damage assessment, and settlement support.

 

In addition, LRC's EMS teams are ready to respond to any mission and upscale the availability of the teams upon the need, whereas the DMS teams will continue the provision of relief services and support with the evacuation when needed; The DRR teams will be participating in the awareness raising on earthquake topics on a national level, stressing on the schools and vulnerable areas as agreed with the Lebanese Government in the meeting that took place on the 6th of February, 2023 in the Grand Serail.

 

Under close coordination with the authorities, LRC is also in the process of assessing risks and needs related to the weather conditions in the country and the aftereffects of the earthquake.

 

At last, the Lebanese government has asked LRC to deploy a Team to Turkey along with the Civil Defense and Army to help with the Search and Rescue mission, and the Lebanese Red Cross Secretary General is in close coordination with the IFRC, Turkish Red Crescent, and Syrian Arab Red Crescent to facilitate any further request for assistance.

Adverse conditions intensified by the end of January, thus deepening the already existing vulnerabilities in the country, particularly for populations that are already at risk. 1. LRCs 140 Emergency Hotline received many calls directly after the Earthquake while Emergency Medical Teams has been on alert since 3:20 A.M and transported and treated 18 cases.

2. LRCs Disaster Management Sector has provided support to 600 HHs in Akkar with the provision of blankets, bread and other relief items.

3. LRCs Disaster Risk Reduction Unit launched the dissemination of the earthquake awareness video and the booklet including the main key messages.

appeals.sector: Middle East and North Africa Regional Office

field_reports.description:
Lebanon is experiencing its first outbreak of cholera in a generation at a time when its healthcare and coping capacity is badly eroded by years of complex crises. 
The first case of cholera in the region was detected in Syria on the 10th of September 2022. The virus rapidly spread, crossing the border into Lebanon marking the first reported case in Lebanon in 1993.
The first case in Lebanon was reported on 6 October, and by 13 October, Lebanon had reported 29 confirmed cases in Akkar and Baalbek Governorates according to UNICEF. By 25 October, confirmed cases had increased ten-fold to 305 per the Ministry of Public Health (MoPH).
According to the World Health Organization (WHO), cholera is an acute enteric infection caused by ingesting bacteria present in contaminated water or food. Cholera transmission is closely linked to inadequate access to clean water and poor sanitation facilities.  The disease can spread rapidly, depending on the frequency of exposure, the exposed population, and the setting. Symptoms vary from mild to severe diarrhea, vomiting, and dehydration (Center for Disease Control and Prevention, 2020). Cholera affects both children and adults and can be fatal if untreated. However, it is an easily treatable disease. Most people can be treated successfully through prompt administration of oral rehydration solution.

results.summary: Lebanon is experiencing its first outbreak of cholera in a generation at a time when its healthcare and coping capacity is badly eroded by years of complex crises. The first case of cholera in the region was detected in Syria on the 10th of September 2022. The virus rapidly spread, crossing the border into Lebanon marking the first reported case in Lebanon in 1993. The first case in Lebanon was reported on 6 October, and by 13 October, Lebanon had reported 29 confirmed cases in Akkar and Baalbek Governorates according to UNICEF. By 25 October, confirmed cases had increased ten-fold to 305 per the Ministry of Public Health (MoPH). According to the World Health Organization (WHO), cholera is an acute enteric infection caused by ingesting bacteria present in contaminated water or food. Cholera transmission is closely linked to inadequate access to clean water and poor sanitation facilities. The disease can spread rapidly, depending on the frequency of exposure, the exposed population, and the setting. Symptoms vary from mild to severe diarrhea, vomiting, and dehydration (Center for Disease Control and Prevention, 2020). Cholera affects both children and adults and can be fatal if untreated. However, it is an easily treatable disease. Most people can be treated successfully through prompt administration of oral rehydration solution.
results.name: LBN: Epidemic - 2022-10 - Cholera Outbreak Response

field_reports.summary: Lebanon - North Lebanon, Akkar - Tanker explosion
field_reports.description:
The Lebanese Red Cross has responded to an explosion of a fuel tanker in Tlil- Akkar in North Lebanon.
primary information of the response:
-	75 EMT volunteers and 24 ambulances,
-	79 cases transported to the nearest hospitals and treated on site,
-      109 blood units and plasma delivered and 50 units collected
-	20 dead bodies transported to the hospitals in the area. 

In addition, LRC is currently transferring the casualties to other hospitals in Tripoli and some others in Beirut and Mount Lebanon. 

The Lebanese Red Cross Blood Transfusion Centers in Halba and Tripoli, mobilized, were collecting and distributing blood and plasma units. The Blood Transfusion Centers in Beirut, Mount Lebanon, and Tyr supported in providing blood and plasma units to reach a total of 169 units. The BTS  centers are going on collecting units to be provided as per the needs. 
The Lebanese Red Cross Teams are on alert at the site of the explosion to provide the needed support and search for the missing as well as provide emergency support and blood and plasma units. 

ICRC are on the ground cooordinating with LRC and supporting hospitals with the provision of War Wounded kits x 1 (75 boxes, can cover 50 patients severely wounded) and Burn kits x 2 (covers 25 patients with burns) in Tripoli, Al Salam hospital and in Beirut, Geaitaoui hospital.

RFL responders are activated.

The Lebanese Red Cross received calls for support from the delegations of the International Movement of the Red Cross and Red Crescent societies.

results.name: Lebanon - North Lebanon, Akkar - Tanker explosion

field_reports.description: In light of the fire that occurred in Qobayyat - North Lebanon on 28 July 2021, LRC responded with 27 EMS volunteers, 9 ambulances, and 1 van, where 17 civilians were evacuated while 6 cases were transported to the nearest hospital and 24, were treated on-site noting that LRC fixed 5 staging points to treat cases accordingly. In addition, the DMS supported the evacuation process with 27 volunteers and 7 cars. Also, 1 person lost his life while helping in ceasing the fire.
